metadata.case_name: Appellant in C.A. No. 1453/1969 & Writ Petitioners (Sugar Factories) v. State of Andhra Pradesh
metadata.case_number: Civil Appeal No. 1453 of 1969; Writ Petition Nos. 183, 249, 240 of 1971, 3, 105, 134 of 1972

facts.text: The appellant and the petitioners are sugar factories in the State of Andhra Pradesh.

Sugar factories applied under section 21(3) of the Andhra Pradesh Sugarcane (Regulation of Supply and Purchase) Act, 1961 for exemption from the tax payable under sub-section (1) on the ground that they had substantially expanded.
Government of Andhra Pradesh refused the requests for exemption.
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated 29th November 1968 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in Writ Appeal No. 345 of 1968.
Writ petitions filed under Article 32 of the Constitution for enforcement of fundamental rights.
Government adopted a policy of granting exemption from payment of purchase tax only to new and expanded sugar factories in the Co-operative Sector.
No expanded factory, even co-operative, has been granted exemption.
New co-operative sugar factories granted exemption only for one year as against three years contemplated by the Act.
Appellant in Civil Appeal No. 1453 of 1969 holds 1247 out of 1280 shares by cane growers.

Government letter (Annexure III dated 6th Jan. 1968) to appellant stating policy to grant exemption only to co-operative sector factories, refusing request due to financial position and precedent concerns.
State counter-affidavit states applications of each petitioner considered on merits and refused.
Earlier judgment in Andhra Sugars Ltd. v. A.P. State (1968) 1 SCR 505 upheld constitutional validity of section 21(3).

legal_issues.text: Whether the Government can fetter its discretion under section 21(3) by adopting a policy of granting exemption only to co-operative sugar factories, without considering individual merits of applications from expanded factories.
Whether the word 'may' in section 21(3) should be read as 'shall', making grant of exemption obligatory for eligible factories.
Whether co-operative sugar factories consisting of sugarcane growers form a distinct category justifying preferential treatment for exemption.

petitioner_arguments.text: Applications of each factory should be considered on merits; Government cannot fetter discretion by policy granting exemption only to co-operative sugar factories as it has no nexus to object of the Act.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Section 21(3); Andhra Sugars Ltd. v. A.P. State (1968) 1 SCR 505; S.A. de Smith Judicial Review of Administrative Action

petitioner_arguments.text: Classification based on co-operative vs private lacks rational nexus; all new/expanded factories form one class.
Grant of exemption under section 21(3) is obligatory; 'may' should be read as 'shall'.

respondent_arguments.text: Discretion under section 21(3) allows policy decisions based on state of industry, financial position; co-operative factories (cane growers) are distinct category.
Each application considered on merits; policy not fettering discretion but guided by relevant considerations like sucrose content variations, production per acre.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Andhra Sugars Ltd. v. A.P. State (1968) 1 SCR 505

court_reasoning.text: Discretion under section 21(3) is wide; Government can adopt policy to exempt only certain classes like co-operative factories, considering industry state, area differences; policy relevant and not frustrating Act's purpose.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Co-operative sugar factories consisting of sugarcane growers fall under a distinct category different from other categories.

court_reasoning.text: Government considered applications on merits before applying policy; letter shows careful consideration; policy not rigid for all times.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Authority may adopt policy if willing to hear exceptions; here, ears not shut.

court_reasoning.text: 'May' in section 21(3) confers discretion, not obligation; legislature delegated to Government without rigid standards.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Policy behind Act encourages new/expanded factories but exercise considers relevant factors.

court_reasoning.text: Dissent: Policy to confine exemption to co-operative sector fetters discretion, no nexus to object of incentivizing expansion; must consider merits without precluding by policy; quash Annexure III and direct reconsideration.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Classification arbitrary; all expanded factories stand on same footing for incentive.

holdings.text: Government justified in adopting policy limiting exemption to co-operative sector; no fetter on discretion as applications considered on merits; co-operative factories distinct class.
Section 21(3) confers discretion, not mandatory obligation to grant exemption.

precedents_cited.case_name: Andhra Sugars Ltd. v. A.P. State
precedents_cited.relevance: Upheld validity of section 21(3); discretion properly delegated.

precedents_cited.case_name: R. v. Port of London Authority
precedents_cited.relevance: Distinction between legitimate policy after hearing and rigid rule refusing to hear.
Refusal frustrating statute object; not applicable here.

precedents_cited.case_name: British Oxygen v. Minister of Technology
precedents_cited.relevance: Authority can adopt precise policy if listens to applications.

precedents_cited.case_name: R. v. Torquay Licensing JJ., ex p. Brockman
precedents_cited.relevance: Policy must be reconcilable with Act; consider individual cases.
Must not pursue consistency at expense of merits.

statutes_cited.name: Andhra Pradesh Sugarcane (Regulation of Supply and Purchase) Act, 1961
statutes_cited.relevance: Levy of tax on cane purchase; power to remit/exempt new/expanded factories; discretion to Government.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Equality; enforcement of fundamental rights via writs.

outcome.summary: The appeal and writ petitions challenging the refusal of tax exemption under section 21(3) on grounds of fettered discretion by policy favouring co-operative factories were dismissed following the majority judgment, holding the policy valid and applications duly considered.

key_quotes.text: "The establishment of new factories and the expansion of the existing factories need encouragement and incentives. The exemption in favour of new and expanding factories is based on legitimate legislative policy."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: From earlier judgment, upholding Sec 21(3) validity.

key_quotes.text: "Co-operative sugar factories consisting of sugarcane growers fall under a distinct category different from other categories."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "A tribunal entrusted with a discretion must not, by the adoption of a general rule of policy, disable itself from exercising its discretion in individual cases."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Cited from de Smith; limits on policy adoption.

key_quotes.text: "The policy or rule adopted by the State Government is not legally relevant to the exercise of the power of granting exemption."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Dissent's crux on lack of nexus.
